options.option_text: Predicted number of run Indian Cricket team will score in their next ODI.
Amount of money that Amitabh Bachchan’s next three movies each will make.
Predicting number of goals Ronaldo will score in next 10 matches each.
Predicting blood group of a person

questions.question_text_1: In a random forest model let p < m be the number of randomly selected features that are used to identify the best split at any node of a tree. Which of the following are true? (m is the original number of features)
question_texts: In a random forest model let p < m be the number of randomly selected features that are used to identify the best split at any node of a tree. Which of the following are true? (m is the original number of features)

options.option_text: Increasing p reduces the correlation between any two trees in the forest.
Decreasing p reduces the correlation between any two trees in the forest.
Increasing p increases the performance of individual trees in the forest.
Decreasing p increases the performance of individual trees in the forest.

questions.question_text_1: Consider a neural network for a multi-class, image classification problem. When the network is trained on the images as they are, it does a good job on the test data. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D1 and the network N1. Assume that we now turn all images upside down, in both the training and test dataset. Now, the network with the same architecture is trained from scratch on this modified dataset. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D2 and network N2. Select the most appropriate option.
question_texts: Consider a neural network for a multi-class, image classification problem. When the network is trained on the images as they are, it does a good job on the test data. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D1 and the network N1. Assume that we now turn all images upside down, in both the training and test dataset. Now, the network with the same architecture is trained from scratch on this modified dataset. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D2 and network N2. Select the most appropriate option.

options.option_text: The network N2 will not be able to learn anything from D2. Its test accuracy onD2 will be very low.
The network N2 will be able to learn useful patterns from D2. In fact, theperformance of network N2 on D2 will be similar to N1 on D1.
The network N2 will be able to learn somewhat useful patterns from D2. Butthe performance of N1 on D1 will be much better than N2 on D2.
Statement-1 is correct, statement-2 is incorrect
Statement-1 is incorrect, statement-2 is correct
Both statements 1 & 2 are correct
Both statements 1 & 2 are incorrect

questions.question_text_1: A Gaussian Naive Bayes model is trained for a multi-class classification problem that has 12 features and 5 classes. Find the total number of parameters that have to be estimated for this model. Consider each parameter to be a scalar value. In other words, if we decide to store all the parameters in a Python list, with each element of the list being a float value corresponding to a single parameter, what is the size of this list? Ignore the priors in the calculation. Only focus on the parameters of the class conditional densities.
question_texts: A Gaussian Naive Bayes model is trained for a multi-class classification problem that has 12 features and 5 classes. Find the total number of parameters that have to be estimated for this model. Consider each parameter to be a scalar value. In other words, if we decide to store all the parameters in a Python list, with each element of the list being a float value corresponding to a single parameter, what is the size of this list? Ignore the priors in the calculation. Only focus on the parameters of the class conditional densities.

questions.question_text_1: A multi-class classification problem has 5 classes. The training dataset has n data-points, with an equal number of points from each of the 5 classes. Consider a dummy classifier that does prediction as follows: for each input data-point, it picks one of the 5 classes at random (uniformly) and outputs that as its prediction. What is the accuracy of the model on the training dataset as n becomes very large? Your answer should be between 0 and 1. Enter your answer correct to two decimal places.  Hint: Think about it in the probabilistic sense.
question_texts: A multi-class classification problem has 5 classes. The training dataset has n data-points, with an equal number of points from each of the 5 classes. Consider a dummy classifier that does prediction as follows: for each input data-point, it picks one of the 5 classes at random (uniformly) and outputs that as its prediction. What is the accuracy of the model on the training dataset as n becomes very large? Your answer should be between 0 and 1. Enter your answer correct to two decimal places.  Hint: Think about it in the probabilistic sense.

questions.question_text_1: If Wij is the weight of the edge from neuron i in layer l − 1 to neuron j in layer l, which of the following statements about the matrix W are true? Neurons in a layer are processed (indexed) from top to bottom. So, the first neuron in a layer is the top-most neuron in that layer.
question_texts: If Wij is the weight of the edge from neuron i in layer l − 1 to neuron j in layer l, which of the following statements about the matrix W are true? Neurons in a layer are processed (indexed) from top to bottom. So, the first neuron in a layer is the top-most neuron in that layer.

options.option_text: The first row of the matrix corresponds to all outgoing connections from thefirst neuron in layer l − 1.
The first row of the matrix corresponds to all incoming connections to the firstneuron in layer l .
The last column of the matrix corresponds to all incoming connections to thelast neuron in layer l .
The last column of the matrix corresponds to all the outgoing connectionsfrom the last neuron in layer l − 1.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**
### **1. Supervised Learning**
#### **A. Linear Models**
- **Perceptron Algorithm**
  - Convergence: Guaranteed for linearly separable data (independent of learning rate `α` if small enough).
  - Update rule:
    \[
    w_{t+1} = w_t + \alpha \cdot (y_i - \hat{y}_i) \cdot x_i
    \]
  - Decision boundary: \( w^T x + b = 0 \).

- **Logistic Regression**
  - Sigmoid function: \( \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} \).
  - Loss (log loss):
    \[
    L(w) = -\sum_{i=1}^n [y_i \log(\hat{y}_i) + (1 - y_i) \log(1 - \hat{y}_i)]
    \]
  - Decision boundary: \( w^T x = \log\left(\frac{T}{1-T}\right) \) (where \( T \) is the threshold).
  - Probability interpretation: \( P(y=1|x) = \sigma(w^T x) \).

- **Support Vector Machines (SVM)**
  - Hinge loss (for soft-margin SVM):
    \[
    L(w) = \max(0, 1 - y_i (w^T x_i + b)) + \lambda \|w\|^2
    \]
  - Margin: \( \frac{2}{\|w\|} \).
  - Kernel trick: For non-linear boundaries (e.g., polynomial, RBF).

- **Linear Regression**
  - Loss (MSE):
    \[
    L(w) = \frac{1}{2n} \sum_{i=1}^n (w^T x_i - y_i)^2
    \]
  - Gradient:
    \[
    \nabla_w L(w) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n (w^T x_i - y_i) x_i
    \]
  - Regularization (L1/L2):
    - Lasso (L1): \( L(w) + \lambda \|w\|_1 \).
    - Ridge (L2): \( L(w) + \lambda \|w\|_2^2 \).

#### **B. Tree-Based Models**
- **Decision Trees**
  - Splitting criteria:
    - **Gini impurity**: \( G = 1 - \sum_{k=1}^C p_k^2 \).
    - **Entropy**: \( H = -\sum_{k=1}^C p_k \log(p_k) \).
    - **Misclassification error**: \( 1 - \max_k p_k \).
  - Pruning: To avoid overfitting.

- **Random Forest**
  - Ensemble of decision trees.
  - Feature subsampling: Reduces correlation between trees (decreasing `p` increases diversity).
  - Out-of-bag (OOB) error for validation.

- **Gradient Boosting (e.g., AdaBoost)**
  - Sequential training with weighted samples.
  - Stump (weak learner): Single-split decision tree.
  - Sample weights updated based on errors (higher weight for misclassified samples).

#### **C. Neural Networks**
- **Activation Functions**
  - ReLU: \( \text{ReLU}(z) = \max(0, z) \).
  - Sigmoid: \( \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} \).
  - Tanh: \( \tanh(z) = \frac{e^z - e^{-z}}{e^z + e^{-z}} \).
  - Softmax (for multi-class): \( \text{softmax}(z)_i = \frac{e^{z_i}}{\sum_j e^{z_j}} \).

- **Architecture**
  - Fully connected layers: \( W^{l} \in \mathbb{R}^{n_l \times n_{l-1}} \), biases \( b^l \).
  - Parameter count: \( \sum_{l=1}^L (n_l \times n_{l-1} + n_l) \).

- **Training**
  - Backpropagation: Chain rule for gradient computation.
  - Loss functions:
    - Cross-entropy (classification):
      \[
      L = -\sum_{i=1}^n y_i \log(\hat{y}_i)
      \]
    - MSE (regression): As above.

- **Initialization**
  - Xavier/Glorot: Scales weights based on layer sizes to avoid vanishing/exploding gradients.

#### **D. Evaluation Metrics**
- **Classification**
  - Confusion matrix: TP, TN, FP, FN.
  - Precision: \( \frac{TP}{TP + FP} \).
  - Recall: \( \frac{TP}{TP + FN} \).
  - F1-score: \( 2 \cdot \frac{\text{precision} \cdot \text{recall}}{\text{precision} + \text{recall}} \).
  - Accuracy: \( \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN} \).

- **Regression**
  - MSE, RMSE, MAE, \( R^2 \).

- **Multi-label vs. Multi-class**
  - Multi-label: Multiple labels per sample (e.g., predicting goals in 10 matches).
  - Multi-class: Single label from \( C \) classes.

---
### **2. Unsupervised Learning**
#### **A. Clustering**
- **K-Means**
  - Objective: Minimize within-cluster variance:
    \[
    \sum_{i=1}^n \min_{\mu_j \in C} \|x_i - \mu_j\|^2
    \]
  - Silhouette score: Measures cluster cohesion/separation:
    \[
    S_i = \frac{b_i - a_i}{\max(a_i, b_i)}
    \]
    where \( a_i \) = mean intra-cluster distance, \( b_i \) = mean nearest-cluster distance.

- **Hierarchical Clustering**
  - Agglomerative (bottom-up) vs. divisive (top-down).
  - Linkage methods: Single, complete, average.

#### **B. Dimensionality Reduction**
- **PCA**
  - Maximizes variance along principal components.
  - Eigenvalue decomposition of covariance matrix.

---
### **3. Model Evaluation & Selection**
- **Bias-Variance Tradeoff**
  - Underfitting (high bias): Model too simple.
  - Overfitting (high variance): Model too complex (e.g., high-degree polynomial).
  - Regularization: Penalizes complexity (L1/L2).

- **Cross-Validation**
  - K-fold: Split data into \( K \) folds, train on \( K-1 \), validate on 1.

- **Learning Curves**
  - Training vs. validation error as a function of dataset size.

---
### **4. Probabilistic Models**
- **Naive Bayes**
  - Assumes feature independence given class:
    \[
    P(y|x) \propto P(y) \prod_{i=1}^d P(x_i|y)
    \]
  - Parameters: Mean/variance per feature per class (Gaussian NB).

- **Bayesian Networks**
  - Graphical models representing conditional dependencies.

---
### **5. Optimization**
- **Gradient Descent**
  - Update rule:
    \[
    w_{t+1} = w_t - \alpha \nabla_w L(w_t)
    \]
  - Variants: SGD, Mini-batch, Adam.

- **Convexity**
  - For linear models, loss is convex (global minimum exists).

---
### **6. Practical Considerations**
- **Feature Engineering**
  - Dummy variables (for categorical features).
  - Normalization (e.g., \( z \)-score): \( x' = \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} \).

- **Hyperparameter Tuning**
  - Grid search, random search, Bayesian optimization.

- **Imbalanced Data**
  - Resampling (oversampling minority/undersampling majority).
  - Class weights in loss functions.

---
## **Key Equations**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Perceptron update       | \( w_{t+1} = w_t + \alpha (y_i - \hat{y}_i) x_i \)                          |
| Logistic regression     | \( P(y=1|x) = \sigma(w^T x) \), \( \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} \)      |
| SVM hinge loss          | \( \max(0, 1 - y_i (w^T x_i + b)) \)                                        |
| MSE loss                | \( \frac{1}{2n} \sum_{i=1}^n (w^T x_i - y_i)^2 \)                           |
| Cross-entropy loss      | \( -\sum_{i=1}^n y_i \log(\hat{y}_i) \)                                     |
| Gini impurity           | \( 1 - \sum_{k=1}^C p_k^2 \)                                                |
| Entropy                 | \( -\sum_{k=1}^C p_k \log(p_k) \)                                            |
| Softmax                 | \( \text{softmax}(z)_i = \frac{e^{z_i}}{\sum_j e^{z_j}} \)                  |
| Silhouette score        | \( S_i = \frac{b_i - a_i}{\max(a_i, b_i)} \)                                |
| Lasso/Ridge regression  | \( L(w) + \lambda \|w\|_1 \) (Lasso), \( L(w) + \lambda \|w\|_2^2 \) (Ridge) |

---
## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **1. Supervised Learning Hierarchy**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Supervised Learning] --> B[Classification]
    A --> C[Regression]
    B --> D[Linear Models]
    B --> E[Tree-Based]
    B --> F[Neural Networks]
    D --> G[Logistic Regression]
    D --> H[Perceptron]
    D --> I[SVM]
    E --> J[Decision Trees]
    E --> K[Random Forest]
    E --> L[Gradient Boosting]
    F --> M[MLP]
    F --> N[CNN]
    C --> O[Linear Regression]
    C --> P[Polynomial Regression]
```

### **2. Model Evaluation Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Evaluation Metrics] --> B[Classification]
    A --> C[Regression]
    B --> D[Confusion Matrix]
    D --> E[Precision]
    D --> F[Recall]
    D --> G[F1-Score]
    D --> H[Accuracy]
    C --> I[MSE]
    C --> J[RMSE]
    C --> K[R²]
```

### **3. Clustering Algorithms**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Clustering] --> B[K-Means]
    A --> C[Hierarchical]
    A --> D[DBSCAN]
    B --> E[Silhouette Score]
    B --> F[Elbow Method]
    C --> G[Agglomerative]
    C --> H[Divisive]
```

### **4. Neural Network Components**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Neural Network] --> B[Layers]
    A --> C[Activation Functions]
    A --> D[Loss Functions]
    B --> E[Input Layer]
    B --> F[Hidden Layers]
    B --> G[Output Layer]
    C --> H[ReLU]
    C --> I[Sigmoid]
    C --> J[Tanh]
    C --> K[Softmax]
    D --> L[Cross-Entropy]
    D --> M[MSE]
```

### **5. Bias-Variance Tradeoff**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Model Complexity] -->|Low| B[High Bias/Underfitting]
    A -->|High| C[High Variance/Overfitting]
    B --> D[Train Error ≈ Test Error]
    C --> E[Train Error << Test Error]
```

### **6. Dimensionality Reduction**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Dimensionality Reduction] --> B[PCA]
    A --> C[t-SNE]
    A --> D[Autoencoders]
    B --> E[Eigendecomposition]
    B --> F[Variance Maximization]
```
